title: The focus on Esport will be the downfall of this game.
body:
I miss the olden days, when Esports was the byproduct of a game just being that well made that you could play it fairly on a high competitive level, and not the core design principle.

Do you know what Esport-LoL is? it is fucking boring. Two teams dance around each other for 30 minutes, and the one who then makes the firts mistake loses. Pretty much 30 minutes of nothing for a few moments of action. And since that kinda sucked, Riot was like "well, what if we made games faster so they are cooler to watch?", completly disregarding that the esport group, while it is vocal is just an abyssimal minority when compared to the total playerbase of this game.

And now we are where we are now, where people demand a surreder vote at 10 ot 15 minutes, and for the first time since season 2, I see people actually supporting that idea.

You can either have a game that is fun to watch - or fun to play. Both at once is impossible. And since this is supposed to be a GAME, I'd rather have fun in my own matches, even if this means there will be less tounraments where we will figure out who is the best asian at this game.

I only had about 4 or 5 matches in my 3 years of playing League that even made it to 70 minutes. I think only 2 (and that was WAY back in season 3 when I began) that made it to about 2 hours for just one game. I didn't care about dying because it never critically hurt my team (from what I saw) and I never got too over powered from going on a killing spree. You could itemize whatever you felt like (even if its as simple and stupid as just Bloodthirsters or Rabadon Deathcaps) it was fun and we felt like *we* were in control. If I wanted to go AD Teemo probably in that time, no one would had cared as much as they would now. 

Now, not only has Riot done this, they stopped doing fun give aways for the heck of it, they won't give an increase to IP for new players, and game modes are taken away so that players **must** focus on only Normal campaign. You do get a choice in either going in Summoners Rift to play in either a Ranked mode or Normal mode. But it overshadows the Twisted Treeline map. 

I honestly miss how much freedom I had in Team Builder. I miss Trinity Force having AP. I miss the original Zeke's (that should had stayed since we don't have that many support items...). I've lost my will to play. Everyone around me tell me to either quit, do what I feel, or tell of how they don't like the game. I will miss this game. I think the damage creep was the biggest offender. The actual fights are over so much quicker that you don't have time to react to almost anything anymore.

Yeah Starcraft 2 is the prime example of development gone wrong. With WoL they had a simple game with optional complex depth, but not so deep that it was impossible to understand or deal with. Complex plays could be dealt with by simple counterreactions, altho when properly exdcuted were sitll rewarding to the more skilled player.

And then they were like "you know what's cool to watch? Pro-micro-play!". The thing is: 80% of the playerbase got neither the time nor the nerve to extensively deal with unit micro. The game before had been about macro: build orders, ressource allocation, proper scouting and army building... and then there are units that can, with enough APM, eradicate their own value multiuple times, turning the entire concept on its head. Suddenly nothing I meantioned before mattered, now it became 100% micro skills, and less strategy.

And so people stopped playeing and flocked to other games, simple as that.

I think this is an important point APM is not actually that interesting.  It may take more skill, but that's just it.  It's like you could go into a hyberbolic time chamber and develop some cool skills based on your actions per minute but ultimately it detracts from macroplay.

It would like if the chess federation thought it would be cool if each side took two moves instead of one each turn.  The game would be faster paced and players could coordinate interesting micro plays, but ultimately it wouldn't result in a more interesting and enjoyable game overall.

For the past year and a half riot has specifically stated in articles and patch notes that they're basing more and more balance decisions around "fun" and "interactive gameplay" for both parties. Though they do tend to see-saw back and forth between both sides every now and then when they reference their design policies.  Point is that they're definitely trying for both regardless of whether you think so or not.

Sadly, one issue is that people have different interpretations of fun.

I'd prefer a strategic, objective-oriented game based around controlling vision, map rotations and decision-making.

Others may prefer playing Team Deathmatch and may consider mechanical skill as the be-all-end-all factor.

I'd say that's the real killer. People have been saying that the strategy element of League is dying ever since you could reasonably start saying it. In strategy games, there tend to be things like counters to work around that you have to play around very carefully, assuming it doesn't invalidate you outright, which is a distinct possibility. It's only in mechanically-oriented games that counters stop being very hard and everyone has the chance of playing around anything with anyone. Part of the strategy in a strategy game comes from seeing what the enemy has planned and countering that plan as much as you can while they counter yours, which in itself requires good game sense and long-term thinking so you can enact your plan or improvise a new plan as your current one is countered. 

League doesn't require as much strategic play because it focuses on mechanical play. This isn't to say that the strategy isn't there, but it's not as deep as other games' strategy elements. If I was going to be 100% honest, I'd nod my head in agreement if someone said this game didn't require a ton of strategy just as much as I'd nod if someone says it did require a lot of strategy.

I fundamentally disagree with your statement OP. A game can both be action-packed (fun to watch) and fun to play. League has also continued to grow over the years as well as the Esports scene. In spite of having an extremely saturated player market, Riot manages to capture an even greater base year-to-year. Unless you have substantiate claim that Esports is hurting League, your argument pretty much boggles down to "I'm salty because Riot isn't catering to _my_ gaming tastes". This is very subjective, anecdotal, and not at ALL indicative of how other people feel. I wasn't an Esports fan until last year when I went to see the NA Finals in Toronto; both the atmosphere and Esports community were absolutely electric. If you don't share their taste for it, all the power to you, but don't go around saying that their passion and love for this game - and Riot's focus on it - is a bad thing.
